conclusion: Objects cast shadows due to the light source positioned behind them.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are formed on the ground.
Moving the light source forward changes the angle at which light rays hit the objects.
Shadows will shift backward as the light source moves forward.
Front edges of shadows move closer to objects, back edges retract.
Size of shadows decreases because the light source is closer to the objects.
Closer light source results in narrower spread of light rays, causing smaller shadows.
Shadow A (Cake) moves backward and becomes smaller.
Shadow B (Notepad) moves backward and becomes smaller.
Shadow C (Milk Carton) moves backward and becomes smaller.
Shadow D (Baseball) moves backward and becomes smaller.
All shadows (A, B, C, and D) will shift backward and decrease in size as the light source moves forward.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will shift backward and become smaller.
